required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Single Anastomosis Sleeve Jejunal Bypass Compared to Mini Gastric Bypass and Sleeve Gastrectomy as a Treatment for Morbid Obesity

brief_summary.textblock: 150 morbidly obese patients divided into to equal groups, group A underwent single anastomosis sleeve jejunal bypass with biliary limb length of 200 cm from the duodenal-jejunal flexure and group B underwent mini gastric bypass, group C underwent sleeve gastrectomy. All patients were followed for at least one year. all cases were evaluated as regard BMI, complications, nutritional status and obesity-related comorbidities.

detailed_description.textblock: 150 morbidly obese patients divided into to equal groups, group A underwent single anastomosis sleeve jejunal bypass with biliary limb length of 200 cm from the duodenal-jejunal flexure and group B underwent mini gastric bypass, group C underwent sleeve gastrectomy. All patients were followed for at least one year. all cases were evaluated as regard BMI, complications, nutritional status and obesity-related comorbidities.

primary_outcome.description: percentage of excess weight loss in kilogram

secondary_outcome.description: the incidence of nutritional deficiency like anemia, hypocalcamia, hypoproteinemia.

secondary_outcome.measure: the rate of improved co morbidity
secondary_outcome.description: the effect of the operation on co morbidity like diabetes and hypertension

secondary_outcome.measure: the incidence of early operative complications
secondary_outcome.description: early operative complications like leak, bleeding

arm_group.description: laparoscopic single anastomosis sleeve jejunal bypass

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- obese patients with BMI more than 40 with or without co-morbidity or more than 35 with co-morbidity
- patients fit for laparoscopic surgery
- give approval to share in the study
Exclusion Criteria:
- patients refused to share in the study
- patients unfit for surgery
- patients aged less than 18 and older than 60
- patient with previous upper abdominal surgery either for obesity or other diseases
- revisional bariatric procedures
